text.p: Fugitive Cypriot businessman Asil Nadir will shortly begin a legal process aimed at paving the way for his return to Britain, his lawyer said on Monday.

"I think he will shortly instruct me on his abuse of process application," Peter Krivinskas told Reuters, adding that Nadir would not come back before a decision on this was given. Nadir, who skipped bail in 1993, faces charges connecting to his collapsed Polly Peck empire.
Krivinskas was speaking after Nadir's former financial advisor, Elizabeth Forsyth, had her conviction on two offences of handling stolen goods overturned by a London appeal court.
Forsyth, 60, spent 10 months in jail after she was found guilty of dishonestly handling 400,000 pounds ($640,000) in April last year. Her sentence of five-years in jail was quashed in January.
The outcome of Forsyth's case was widely viewed as an indicator of whether Nadir would would press ahead with attempts to have theft and false accounting charges against him dropped.

Polly Peck, Nadir's fruit-to-electronics empire, collapsed in 1990 under a mountain of debt. Forsyth said she could not say if Nadir would return to Britain but in a statement she encouraged others who had fled from British justice "to return to face trial or judicial inquiry to clear their name". ($ = 0.624 British Pounds)
